subtitle: Triple Goddess of Fire, Poetry, and Healing
name: Brigid

listDisplay.expandedContent: Brigid is one of the most beloved goddesses of Celtic mythology - a triple goddess ruling fire, poetry, healing, and smithcraft. Daughter of the Dagda, she was so important that her worship transitioned seamlessly into Christianity as St. Brigid of Kildare. Her festival Imbolc marks the coming of spring.
listDisplay.primary: Brigid - Triple Goddess of Fire, Poetry, and Healing
listDisplay.secondary: Triple goddess of fire, poetry, healing, and smithcraft. Daughter of the Dagda, honored at Imbolc.

sections.title: Description
sections.content: Brigid is one of the most beloved and important goddesses of Celtic mythology. Often described as a triple goddess - three sisters all named Brigid - she rules over fire, poetry, healing, and smithcraft. As daughter of the Dagda, chief of the Tuatha De Danann, she holds a position of great prestige. Her importance was so enduring that she was seamlessly syncretized into Christianity as St. Brigid of Kildare, one of Ireland's patron saints.

sections.title: The Triple Goddess
sections.content: Brigid is described as three sisters: Brigid the poetess (goddess of poetry and inspiration), Brigid the smith (goddess of the forge and craftsmanship), and Brigid the healer (goddess of medicine and fertility). Together they represent the creative fire that inspires poets, forges metal, and heals the sick. This threefold nature reflects the Celtic affinity for triadic divine figures.

sections.title: Imbolc and the Coming of Spring
sections.content: Brigid's principal festival is Imbolc (February 1-2), marking the coming of spring and the first stirrings of new life. The festival celebrates the lactation of ewes, the lengthening days, and the earth's awakening. Traditional practices include making Brigid's crosses from rushes, lighting candles, and leaving offerings for the goddess. Imbolc represents the promise of warmth returning after winter's cold.

sacred_sites: Holy wells throughout Ireland dedicated to Brigid

description: Brigid is one of the most beloved goddesses of Celtic mythology - a triple goddess ruling over fire, poetry, healing, and smithcraft. Daughter of the Dagda, chief of the Tuatha De Danann, she represents the creative fire that inspires poets, forges metal, and heals the sick. Her importance was so enduring that she was seamlessly syncretized into Christianity as St. Brigid of Kildare, one of Ireland's patron saints. Her festival Imbolc (February 1-2) celebrates the coming of spring.
primarySources: Cath Maige Tuired (Battle of Mag Tuired)

mythsAndLegends.title: The Triple Brigid
mythsAndLegends.summary: Brigid is described as three sisters, all daughters of the Dagda: Brigid the poetess, Brigid the smith, and Brigid the healer. This threefold nature encompasses all creative fire - the fire of inspiration, the fire of the forge, and the fire of healing.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Invention of Keening
mythsAndLegends.summary: When Brigid's son Ruadan was killed in the Battle of Mag Tuired, she mourned with such powerful lamentation that she invented keening (the Irish mourning cry). This was said to be the first time such mourning was heard in Ireland.

mythsAndLegends.title: Marriage to Bres
mythsAndLegends.summary: Brigid married Bres the Beautiful, a half-Fomorian who became king of the Tuatha De Danann. When Bres proved to be a tyrant lacking in generosity, he was deposed, leading to conflict between the Tuatha De Danann and the Fomorians.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Perpetual Flame at Kildare
mythsAndLegends.summary: A perpetual flame was kept burning at Kildare, tended by nineteen priestesses (later nuns). On the twentieth day, Brigid herself was said to tend the flame. This tradition continued into Christian times at St. Brigid's monastery.

worship.temples: Kildare - site of her sacred fire and later monastery
worship.offerings: Milk, butter, bread, candles, Brigid's crosses
worship.practices: Making Brigid's crosses, lighting candles, visiting holy wells, leaving food offerings

iconography.appearance: Depicted as a beautiful woman, often with red or flame-colored hair
iconography.attributes: Carries tools of her domains: forge hammer, healing herbs, poet's staff
iconography.colors: Red, orange, white - colors of fire and purity
iconography.posture: Often shown at the forge or tending sacred flame

conversionContext.description: St. Brigid of Kildare (c. 451-525 CE), one of Ireland's patron saints, shares the name and some attributes of the goddess Brigid. This has generated scholarly debate about Christian inculturation versus syncretism.
conversionContext.significance: The Brigid case illustrates complex dynamics of Christianization in Celtic lands, where Christian saints sometimes took on roles previously attributed to pagan deities.
conversionContext.historicalNote: Kildare's perpetual flame, tended by St. Brigid's community, may reflect pre-Christian fire keeping associated with the goddess.

patristicAndMedievalCommentary.author: Cogitosus
patristicAndMedievalCommentary.commentary: The earliest biography of St. Brigid presents her as a Christian holy woman without explicitly addressing the goddess tradition, demonstrating early medieval approach to inculturation.

typologicalConnections.observation: Brigid's associations with healing, poetry, and crafts reflect valued attributes that Christianity could sanctify rather than suppress.
typologicalConnections.distinction: Christian saints intercede and exemplify holiness; they do not possess divine power independently. St. Brigid's miracles flow from Christ.

typologicalConnections.observation: Fire imagery connects to the Holy Spirit (Acts 2:3) and Christian traditions of perpetual flames.
typologicalConnections.distinction: Christian flame imagery points to God's presence; pagan fire was often the deity itself or its manifestation.

scholarlyEnrichment.methodology: Comprehensive mythological expansion with primary sources, cross-cultural connections, and Christian context
